data.title: More consistent entries under the "Scene" submenu
data.body:
In my opinion "Project Settings", "Quit to Project List" and "Quit" don't belong to the "Scene" submenu. Yes, there are separators between them and the other entries but those functions have nothing to do with scenes. It's especially bad in the case of "Project Settings" - who'd look for (universal) project settings  in the menu for a (partial) scene?

I suggest those entries are moved to a "Project" submenu, for additional consistency.

data.title: Add CTRL+<left/right arrow> and CTRL+SHIFT+<left/right arrow> cursor operations in text inputs
data.body:
In most programs:
- `CTRL+left arrow` moves to the start of the current word or else, the start of the previous word
- `CTRL+shift+left arrow` selects everything from the cursor position to the beginning of the current word, and previous words after repeated presses

The reverse applies for the right arrow. I think this is a simple but important function and should be implemented in Godot's text inputs.

(The text editor already has this functionality, BTW, but it's broken because when you use `CTRL+SHIFT+<left/right key>` and then use `CTRL+<left/right arrow>` the selection stays)

data.title: Scene dock receives input when it shouldn't
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7. Recent 64-bit builds from https://archive.hugo.pro/godot/ and http://fixnum.org/godot/.

**Issue description & repro steps:**
The scene dock now seems to _always_ take input no matter what. In many contexts, Ctrl-A is "select all", but it's also "add node" for the scene dock. Previously, if you were in the script editor or editing a property in the inspector, Ctrl-A would only select all, now it selects all _and_ brings up the add node dialog box, which is obviously undesirable. I don't have a specific date when this started happening, the last build I used was from the 8th and it worked correctly, recent builds from the last few days have the issue. 

There are some contexts in which this happened before, but they weren't as much of a pain. If you open the "project settings" or the "editor settings" menu the scene dock will receive input while that is open, even if you're in the script editor. I'm sure there are other situations that I haven't tried.

data.title: Editor shortcuts don't save
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7. Recent 64-bit builds from https://archive.hugo.pro/godot/ and http://fixnum.org/godot/.

**Issue description & repro steps:**
Set or change any shortcut in the "Shortcuts" tab of the "Editor Settings" panel, yay, the shortcut works! Quit the editor and start it again; all the shortcuts are reset to the defaults. :(

data.title: Blogpost gramatical error
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
http://godotengine.org/article/mir-godot-habla-dein-language-desormais
it says "dein" instead of "deine" here.
the full sentence would be

Hello world, Godot speaks "your language" 'from now on'!
Hallo Welt, Godot spricht 'von jetzt an' "deine Sprache"!

i reordered the last part, because the other way around it really sounds awkward in german.

data.title: A six-month development process between versions (discussion)
data.body:
Now it is not clear how many wait for the new version. This is not good. I propose to go on a six-month development process (as Canonical Ltd (Ubuntu)). 5 months on the development and implementation of new features and 1 month for testing and fix. If something does not have time to simply tolerated in the next version.
Some will ask, and it will change and what advantages does it mean? The answer is: the developer will be able to more flexibly plan the development of the game. For example: we have started to develop the game at 2.0, and we know that in six months there will be version 2.1 with a feature we required. The developer knows whether he has time to move to a new stable version of the engine or whether it needs to implement this feature on their own or even to abandon it. All this nonsense seems at first glance, but for commercial projects with real deadlines is very important.

data.title: remote debug on android does not work straight away - it glitches and requires action to make it work.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7, Godot 2.1 alpha, android 4.4.2 arm

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Even tho you may deploy and run project over wifi adb on remote android device, when enabling option "deploy with remote debug" - The debug does not work. No Output from runing application is received.
This is glitch and can be easly fixed with work around trick, but the trick is not obvious, especially to someone who 100 times browsed all options to make sure everything is properly set.
(see "steps to reproduce" to find out where is glitch and what trick to do to make it work - or rather what should be fixed.)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1 - close godot editor (this step is REQUIRED)
2 - open godot editor (this step is REQUIRED)
3 - open or create any project which use _print("test")_, so you can see... that you will not see it.
4 - start your wifi adb - and then you will see in editor green android icon apear.
5 - check option "deploy with remote debug" (located in menu of last icon in run options tool tab)
6 - click green android icon and your project will run on connected android device.
7 - expect to see your _print("test")_ in editors output window - but no... you will not see it because it not works.
8 - go to settings -> editor settings -> network, and check if the IP is your WIFI where android device is connected. Even if its right IP (!) change it to seomething else and then change back to your WIFI,
9 - now it works, no matter its the same IP that didnt worked while a go - it needed to be shaked up.
10 - It will work as long as you not close godot - next time you will have again "shake" network setting.

data.title: Missing auto save - Editor does not save project before runing on remote device.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7, Godot 2.1 alpha, Android 4.4.2 arm

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Editor save scene / script when user press "Play the project (F5)" or "Play the edited scene (F6)", so it is expected it will also save when run on remote device (click green android button), however it does not save before runing on remote device, which leads to confusion someone who is used to this feature. Personaly it took me fiew hairs and several minutes to discover why im typing and typing and whatever i could type - nothing changes in debug output - it just didnt saved when i ran the code)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Change something in script, run project by F5 key - editor will auto save scene / script then will run it.
Change something in script, run project on remote device by clicking on green android button - editor will NOT save your changes, and will run the old version all around untill you figure out it didnt saved.

data.title: SSL validation failure, sometimes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot compiled at 842e7bf, with `p=x11 bits=64 openssl=builtin`, Xubuntu 16.04 64bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It seems ssl validation sometimes fails on legit sites. I consistently got the following error when switching to the "Templates" tab in project list view. When I open the url (https://raw.githubusercontent.com/KOBUGE-Games/minilens/master/icon.png) in my browser, it showed just fine. This happened to a few other legit SSL sites.

```
REQUEST ICON FOR: 90235184
1 url: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/KOBUGE-Games/minilens/master/icon.png
yes SSL
2 url: raw.githubusercontent.com/KOBUGE-Games/minilens/master/icon.png
request string: /KOBUGE-Games/minilens/master/icon.png
3 url: raw.githubusercontent.com
4 url: raw.githubusercontent.com
Requesting:
    URL: raw.githubusercontent.com
    String: /KOBUGE-Games/minilens/master/icon.png
    Port: 443
    SSL: 1
    Validate SSL: 1
Cause: unable to get local issuer certificate
CERT STR: /C=US/O=DigiCert Inc/OU=www.digicert.com/CN=DigiCert SHA2 High Assurance Server CA
VALID: 0
CONNECTION RESULT: -1
139835301386280:error:14090086:SSL routines:ssl3_get_server_certificate:certificate verify failed:drivers/builtin_openssl2/ssl/s3_clnt.c:1258:

```

What's weird to me was that it was able to validate some sites and grab the content, like https://github.com:

```
1 url: https://github.com
yes SSL
2 url: github.com
no request
3 url: github.com
4 url: github.com
Requesting:
    URL: github.com
    String: /
    Port: 443
    SSL: 1
    Validate SSL: 1
CERT STR: /businessCategory=Private Organization/jurisdictionC=US/jurisdictionST=Delaware/serialNumber=5157550/street=88 Colin P Kelly, Jr Street/postalCode=94107/C=US/ST=California/L=San Francisco/O=GitHub, Inc./CN=github.com
VALID: 1
CONNECTION RESULT: 1
cert_ok: 1
```

data.title: RubberHose: New node for animating
data.body:
Cut out animations in Godot are really good and easy to do. 
BUT if you want to bend a knee or an arm for example then it will look like this:
![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12517768/16285890/23c1dc58-38d9-11e6-90da-8d1e30887c41.png)

Here comes my feature request. Add an object/node which is bendable and whose style you can change (color, border, texture). For After Effects there is a plugin called RubberHose, and it does everything for the problem. 

**Watch this:**
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jn740nc0KUU

![3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12517768/16286127/b45ca206-38da-11e6-93a7-c38e0987a15f.png)

![5](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12517768/16286238/7d13de62-38db-11e6-9486-005038b228d0.png)

data.title: Make editor compatible with Windows high contrast themes
data.body: By providing a manifest specifying the targeted Windows versions (as per [this document](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/hh404233%28v=vs.85%29.aspx#_______supporting_high_contrast_themes_in_windows_8_and_later)) **now the Godot editor renders normally under a high contrast theme on Windows**, instead of staying white/black.

Windows 10 - 64bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Game does not respond when using `Directory.get_current_dir()`
It's fine when running on editor

**Steps to reproduce:**

``` gdscript
func _ready():
    var dir = Directory.new()
    var err = dir.open("res://temp/")
    print("dir open result = ", err)
    print("current path = ", dir.get_current_dir())
```

create `temp` directory under `res://`.
export to windows binary and run.

data.title: libpng: New version 1.6.23
data.body:
Updated libpng to version ~~1.6.27~~ 1.6.23
Needed to fix iCCp chunk in a lot of pngs, since libpng 1.6 is more strict in this matter. See [[1]](https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/125612/warning-pdflatex-libpng-warning-iccp-known-incorrect-srgb-profile) [[2]](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22745076/libpng-warning-iccp-known-incorrect-srgb-profile) [[3]](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Libpng_errors).
Projects will also need to fix their pngs if they have an incorrect iCC profile or will receive warnings like:
`ERROR: _png_warn_function: iCCP: known incorrect sRGB profile`
Will do a PR in the godot-docs repo about this, adding some documentation about the errors and fixing them.

fixes #3059, updates: #5248

data.title: Mouse does not update the event MOUSE_MOTION while it's within the window's coordinates.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 64bit - Godot 2.1 alpha (June 21st)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The input event MOUSE_MOTION does not update while the mouse is within the screen coordinates, it only updates while it's outside the coordinates (which can be achieved with MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED). For example if the window is 800x600 the MOUSE_MOTION will not start updating until its x position is greater than 800 or less than 0, or its y position is greater than 600 or less than 0.

Some more info: This problem wasn't happening from a build on June 16th. So the problem started somewhere between the 16th and 21st.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
In the Window Management demo, click on the "Mouse Grab" button and try to move the mouse, it wont start moving until you've moved the mouse far enough away.

Fixed save as not working with scripts.

data.title: RigidBody2D is passing through tilemap
data.body:
2.0.3 steam release (on Linux)

How to reproduce:
1. The tilemap was created like so: Sprite > StaticBody2D > with CollisionPolygon2D
2. I exported it as `basic.xml`
3. I then imported into a new scene with `TileMap`; created a `RigidBody2D` sprite, built a basic map and put the `RigidBody2D`, enabled collision bounds with debug and started the scene. The `RigidBody2D` then passed through the `TileMap`; there were no collision lines for the created TileMap. Kinematic collision was enabled on the TileMap. In the below tutorial (see XML part of it) I did not see any collision data in the XML file.

I was following [this tutorial](http://www.gamefromscratch.com/post/2015/04/28/Godot-Engine-Tutorial-Part-8-Tilemaps.aspx)

data.title: Added alert() functionality for OS X
data.body: Fills in the blank for OS X, since the `alert()` seemingly didnt do anything (it actually printed something to `stderr`, which could go undetected).

data.title: fix android resource locale
data.body:
from lint reports
# LocaleFolder: Wrong locale name

```
../../res/values-he: The locale folder "he" should be called "iw" instead; see the java.util.Locale documentation
../../res/values-id: The locale folder "id" should be called "in" instead; see the java.util.Locale documentation
```

Priority: 6 / 10
Category: Correctness
Severity: Warning
Explanation: Wrong locale name.

From the java.util.Locale documentation:
"Note that Java uses several deprecated two-letter codes. The Hebrew ("he") language code is rewritten as "iw", Indonesian ("id") as "in", and Yiddish ("yi") as "ji". This rewriting happens even if you construct your own Locale object, not just for instances returned by the various lookup methods.

Because of this, if you add your localized resources in for example values-he they will not be used, since the system will look for values-iw instead.

To work around this, place your resources in a values folder using the deprecated language code instead.

More info: http://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/Locale.html

To suppress this error, use the issue id "LocaleFolder" as explained in the Suppressing Warnings and Errors section.

data.title: Meaningful names for built-in scripts
data.body:
Before:
![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11797174/16260267/ec95f43e-3866-11e6-9f62-4107e7739f86.png)

After:
![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11797174/16260269/f1915fe6-3866-11e6-9bc1-833964dc2456.png)

Every object now will keep a pointer to the script attached to it in case it is internal (built-in). That way the script editor can show a meaningful name for it in the open scripts list. That is, instead of the cryptic and difficult to identify `GDScript(NNNNN)` now it will appear as `OwnerNodeName <Built-In>`.

User still has the option of giving an explicit name to the internal script resource and it will appear instead, but this change makes it a lot less needed.

The naming algorithm still will have to resort to the old notation in cases when the owner object is no longer present; e.g., when the scene has been closed but the script is still open in the editor.

Overall this makes easier to work with built-in scripts. I find them more convenient when a small amount of code is needed for a node in order to balance filesystem pollution against scene file complexity.

data.title: iOS simulator: merge into iphone detect.py
data.body:
**Please test,** as I did not. It should now be possible to build the iOS simulator with `scons p=iphone ios_sim=yes`. It should enforce the right flags.

As the main iphone detect.py and the isim one had diverged a bit in some points, there might be further work needed to get the simulator to build. A notable difference is that the simulator defaulted to building in tools mode, while after this commit it would default to template mode; should I force tools mode for the simulator?

CC @punto- and anyone with an Xcode/OSXCross environment.

Fixes #4489

data.title: Editor Shortcuts: Scene shortcuts don't work until focus has been given on a UI element
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Mageia 6, Linux 64-bit - Current master HEAD (0266d75)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After opening a project via the project manager or the command line, the shortcuts of the Scene menu like <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>O</kbd> do not work at first, though they used to before the addition of the Editor Shortcuts API.

To get them to work, you need to click the Viewport or a dock to give them the focus. Then the shortcuts work.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open an editor, don't click anywhere
2. Try <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>O</kbd>, see that it doesn't work
3. Click on the Viewport
4. Try <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>O</kbd>, see that it works.

data.title: DirAccess: Folder creation fails in "Save As.." on Linux
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Mageia 6, Linux 64-bit - Current master HEAD (0266d75)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Creating new folders in the "Save As.." EditorFileDialog does not work. It just returns a popup saying "Alert! Could not create folder.".
I checked and I have proper write permissions in the concerned folders. Looks like a regression from recent DirAccess changes.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open the "Save As.." dialog
2. Press "Create Folder", enter a name and press "OK"

complex trees.

data.title: Fix classes.xml sorting
data.body:
Now methods, signals, members, theme items and constants are always sorted alphabetically. Constants are sorted by value if they have the same `PREFIX_` otherwise alphabetically.

This made a huge diff for the re-ordered stuff in classes.xml. From a glance it seems to have kept everything in the right place.
